De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Thu, 25 Jun 2015 00:18:04 +0200 (CEST)
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: bon anniversaire

Dear R,

in our hearts and in our thoughts, we will always be together, forever. And compared to infinity, two months does not feel that long... But you are right, having things to do helps a lot. For me, last week passed away quickly, because I had a conference. And I'm sure that once you are in China, time will pass faster for you. Thinking about it, I find myself in a paradoxical situation. On the one hand, when I think about you, I just feel a strong desire to meet you again, and time does not pass at all. On the other hand, the thought of you gives me motivation and energy to work really, really hard, and when I am completely absorbed in my work, then time does pass faster. So, in total, does time pass more quickly or more slowly?

Oh yes, that experience you are describing is an absolute classic, I think that every mathematician goes through these situations many many times. I remember once when I was doing my PhD, I thought I had a brilliant idea, which would solve a main problem of my thesis. So I made an appointment with my advisor the next morning. But later in the evening, when I thought about it again, my argument fell apart. So the meeting the next day was very embarrassing. Fortunately, my advisor was sympathetic and not angry with me :-) Some time after that, I did manage to solve the problem. And you can imagine that I checked everything many many times :-D Although these failures seem to lead nowhere, I think that they are actually quite important. We can learn a lot and gain some insights, in particular if we understand what exactly went wrong, and why.

I came back yesterday night. It was a short conference, and for me, it was even shorter than expected: My plan was to take a flight to Aberdeen arriving around lunchtime. However, at the airport they told me that my flight was canceled. There was even no explanation why. So they put me in a flight to Edinburgh, and I had to go by train to Aberdeen, which took another three hours or so. In the end, I arrived around dinnertime. Fortunately, my talk was the next morning. At first, I was really annoyed. But at some point, I told myself that there is nothing I could do, so I just relaxed and took it easy. And actually, the train ride from Edinburgh to Aberdeen is very nice, most of it is along the coast, with a view of the sea. So at least not everything was bad.

Oh, you're right, I didn't explain the moving activity well :-) Let me try again: Currently, our offices are on one side of the building which faces the place where the new building will be built. While they are constructing the new building, they also have to work on that part of the old building, maybe to connect the two. Besides, since our old offices are close to the construction site, it would be very noisy. That is why we have to move to another part of the old maths building. Once the new building is finished, we move there, and they work on the remaining part of the old maths building. So when you visit me, the maths department will be a complete mess. But I suppose we are not going to spend that much time in my office anyway ;-)

Best wishes,
X

From: r.x@e.fr <r.x@e.fr>
Sent: Tuesday, June 23, 2015 7:27 PM
To: X L
Subject: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: bon anniversaire

Dear X,

I can totally understand your excitement, because I feel exactly the same as you :-) But from now, it seems that two months is really a longtime, maybe it's better to keep myself busy so that the time will pass faster (at least I hope so). Yes, "forever" is a beautiful word for me, it is a word with strong emotion and I also find a similar word in mathematics, which is the symbol of "infinity" :-) I like this symbol very much, and some times ago, I found out that a girl in our office has the tattoo of this symbol, I got excited and told her I also like it.

Yesterday afternoon I thought I might have solved the problem of the main theorem I'm working on, I got so happy, but I checked it last night, it turned out I had made a huge mistake, so now, I have to start all over again :-) Will you do back tonight? And how is it?

I'm sorry, but I didn't get it, why you need to move out when another building is started to be built :-) A maths building with a roofgarden? That must be wonderful. And I don't know that Black Forest cake is that sweet, maybe just because the cake I tasted is not authentic enough :-)

Best wishes,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Dimanche 21 Juin 2015 14:57:10
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: bon anniversaire

Dear R,

this is wonderful news indeed! When I read that you got your visa, I could feel my heart beating faster than usual, so big is my excitement! I'm relieved that everything worked out. Well done :-) A look at the calendar tells me that there two months left now. So time does pass, slowly, but steadily. And then, we'll meet again! I feel such a desire to see you, it is hard to describe in words, the feeling is so strong...

I recently came across a song by The Beach Boys called "Forever", and I immediately liked it. Maybe it's mainly because of the lyrics, they start like this "If every word I said Could make you laugh I'd talk forever I ask the sky just what we had It shone forever If the song I sing to you Could fill your heart with joy I'd sing forever ..."

My first time in O was in 2009, so seven years ago. There were two years with two meetings. Some time ago, a colleague celebrated his first birthday in O, he has spent more than 52 weeks there! Yes, Black Forest cake is famous for that region, and it's very popular. I also like it, but it's very sweet, maybe a bit too much if I'm honest :-)

Next month, they start to build our new maths building. It will be next to the old one. Once the new building is finished, they will renovate the old one. So next week, we have to move. The whole construction is supposed to take two years, but people already gossip that it will take much longer. Hopefully, it won't be too noisy. It will definitely bring some inconveniences, for instance, I will have to temporarily share an office with a colleague. But the new building is supposed to be very nice, it will even have a roofgarden :-)

Yes, it is better to teach less so that you can concentrate on the quality of your teaching. I think it will be a very interesting and helpful experience. As always, every challenge helps you to develop and improve. And I'm sure that you will try your best :-)

Best wishes,
X

I'm so excited that I received my passport and Visa yesterday afternoon, and I want to tell you this good news as soon as I can, so now I will say, see you in London!

Yesterday, I talked to the person in charge of teaching, finally, he decided to let me give the course of mathematiques for students who are not in our departement, maybe in biology. It takes just 38 hours, which is less heavy. But in fact, in some sense, we both think it is more difficult to explain the math for those who don't do math, which requires more language abilities, anyway, he gave me a chance to have a try, and I will do my best, so there are lots of things to prepare this summer...But after the summer, I will have a wonderful trip to London with you, it's really good to have something to look forward :-D

Best wishes, and have a nice weekend,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>

Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: bon anniversaire

Dear R,

your story with the rain made me smile and feel sorry at the same time. I had to smile because of the irony of the situation. Maybe it was because the rain read the part of your email where you expressed your love, and decided to love you back, in its own way ;-) But then, more seriously, I hope that you didn't have a long way to go. At least you were home afterwards and could get dry and warm. It would be worse if the rain would have caught you on your way somewhere else. Actually, it rained quite a bit in O this week. The view was very nice, because we were in the mountains, so that the clouds were very low and the forest was covered by mist. When a colleague said to me that the rain is nice to watch, I thought to myself: "Yes, as long as we are indoor and dry." As though I knew your story already...

I also had an experience with rain. At some point last year, I went back to Muenster just for a few days. And exactly on one of these days, it rained heavily. Really heavily. I had never seen something like this before. It was even in the German news. Afterwards, our basement was under water, not much, but it took us one day to get the water out of it, and it took weeks to dry. Later on, we found out that other people had much bigger problems, so that we were rather lucky.

Back to O: I checked, and found out that this week was my 9th time in O. I hadn't realize myself. In the O photo collection, there are even some photos of me, as an individual :-) And yes, it is really helpful to read some talks, or to see some slides. For example, these things help a lot if we want to get an overview, or if we want to understand motivations or central ideas.

I just arrived in London. Next Monday, I have another conference in Aberdeen (Scotland). It's a bit too much, but the conference is only for two days, and after that, things get more quiet, which is good.

Did you find a good solution for your teaching next semester?

Best wishes,
X

Dear X,

I saw the homepage today, there are many informations about its library, I saw the picture, at first, I thought it was a comprehensive library with all kinds of books, then I realized it is just for mathematics! No wonder it is famous, it is really big! I also found a list of all the talks in the recent years, and then I found a talk given by Junge in 2013 in this workshop about the pseudo-differential operator is quite interesting, it's like a windfalls :-) There are photos of the participants every two years, so I understand why you said that you kind of grow up there :-)

Yes, it still rains, but it's quite tragic today. It has been sunny all the day yesterday and today morning, so I didn't take my umbrella to the office today, but when I was about to leave the office before dinner, it began to rain very heavily... It was already late, there no one else in our office, so I stayed there for another half an hour waiting for the rain to stop, but it never stopped, finally I had to walk home in the heavy rain... It's really funny for me that I just said I love the rain, and it puts me in this situation today :-)

I have already bought the ticket to China, I will leave on 6 July and go back on 13 August. Yes, we had the meeting yesterday, but I will still meet the responsible person of teaching tomorrow since I find the teaching task is too much for me, there will be three classes every week, and I have no experience before, so it might take too much time to prepare and I'm not sure I can do it well. Anyway, we will try to find a solution tomorrow.

Best wishes,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Thu, 18 Jun 2015 00:01:23 +0200 (CEST)
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: bon anniversaire

Dear R,

thank you for giving me this wonderful picture, how you enjoy the rain, listening to the raindrops, feeling comfortable, quiet and peaceful... Is it still raining? I also feel that rain has something refreshing and cleaning, and apart from practical issues like when I have to cycle through rain, I enjoy it a lot, the sound of raindrops on the window, and especially the moment just after the rain, which is very clean and clear. But at the same time, if it has been rainy or cloudy for several days in a row, I am actually quite happy to see the sun. Weather has a big influence on our mood, hasn't it?

O is a wonderful place; for me, it's unique. I told you about the surroundings, but there is also a beautiful library, people say that if you can't find something in O, then probably nowhere else. I remember someone starting his talk by saying that just sitting in the library makes him ten times smarter than usual :-) And lots of interesting people come together, usually these are the experts in the field. For instance this now is the NG workshop, which takes place every two years. The talks, the discussions, the social aspects, all this creates an atmosphere which is unique in my eyes. I gave my talk on Monday this time, and it was great to get rid of that already at the beginning. In some sense, I grew up with O, since my advisor is one of the organizers, so I was so lucky to have come here already several times. And there are some traditions, for instance, every Wednesday, we hike to a small village in the Black Forest, have a piece of cake at a local cafe, hike back, and then have a barbeque. And today is (or was) Wednesday :-D

Yes, after watching "The Imitation Game", I was also quite sad, and angry, too, seeing what Turing had to endure after the great service he did. He was actually only pardoned two years ago. His personal life was sort of tragic. And feeling regret is one of the most scary things in life. But it's probably unavoidable, just like what you wrote about our fears. All we can do is to try our best to make the right decisions, to do well what is in our hands, and to take responsibility.

By the way, I am still keeping this piece of paper you gave me with your email address in your handwriting :-)

How is your week going? Has the meeting about teaching already taken place? And have you bought your flight ticket to China?

Best wishes,
X

From: r.x@e.fr <r.x@e.fr>

Dear X,

Your trip to O seems wonderful to me, not to mention the amazing "Hogwarts train"! Now I can even smell the scent of grass and trees in the air there... It's lucky to be a mathematician that sometimes you can go to the lovely places for a conference, isn't it? Have you already given the speech, and how is the conference?

It has been rainy in B since Sunday, and it will rain all this week. This is quite a good news for me, it makes the weather less hot, and more importantly, I like the rain very much, yes, it makes some inconvenience sometimes, but I really enjoy the time sitting next to the window, listening the sound of rain, breathing the fresh air, and writing to you at this moment, it makes me feel the world is quite and peaceful :-)

This weekend, I watched "The Imitation Game". What Joan said to Turing when he revealed he was homosexual gave me a deep impression, they really accompanied each other in their own way, it is very sad that he never been able to get the reply from his beloving Christopher after he encrypted "I love you" in the note but still he got a friend Joan understood him very well. And at the end of the story his lonely back after he turned off the light also made me feel life is full of regrets...

Best wishes,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Fri, 12 Jun 2015 09:05:55 +0200 (CEST)
Objet: Re: bon anniversaire

Dear R,

you are an angel :-) Thank you so much! You have given me two wonderful birthday presents: Talking to you on skype, and now your wonderful email. I really enjoyed skyping with you, it made me feel very relaxed and close to you, as though our conversations in Wuhan were just yesterday. And then your email on my birthday, I had to read it over and over again, I stopped counting how many times, your stories and feelings mean a lot to me! Afterwards, I sat in my room and recalled our first week in Wuhan, like a little boy opening his treasure box :-) And I have a lot of memories; how you were surprised that I can talk Mandarin; that the hotel wanted to charge my credit card and how you saved me; how you told me that you like romantic movies, movies with feelings, and that one of your favourite movies is Dead Poets Society; that you asked about ice cream at the restaurant where we had lunch, just because you learned two days ago that I like ice cream; how we looked at each other at boring dinner tables and both had to smile... I could continue this list, it would take me forever :-) By the end of the week, we already developed a deep understanding, so that one look was enough to know what the other one was thinking. Deep down in my heart, I had the feeling that you were special, that we have many many things in common. And in the past month, writing to each other, this initial feeling indeed proved to be true, we discovered that we do share the same feelings, similar hopes and fears, like soulmates. It is wonderful to find someone like you! I guess that's why we have to trust our hearts. Like you, I always enjoy writing to you and reading your emails, sharing little pieces of our lives, it's always interesting and exciting, never boring or trivial :-D It makes us get to know each other better and better. There is a German saying: "Geteilte Freude ist doppelte Freude, geteiltes Leid is halbes Leid." It means that sharing happiness doubles the happiness, and sharing sorrow halves the sorrow. Thank you for sharing!

I had a wonderful day yesterday, very nice indeed. And now I am 30. 30. Thirty. It's just a number, isn't it? We are only as old as we feel. What really matters is not the age, but the things that happen in our lives, and the people we meet. I have met you. And I really feel that this does start a new chapter in my life. I can't wait to read the next pages, I'm excited to find out what they contain, what is going to happen next. Are you ready to discover all this together with me?

Best wishes,
X

PS: Good luck in Paris! Hopefully, everything will go well.

Dear R,

I very much like what you said, that our fears and sad moments "make us cherish what we have". I couldn't say it better. There is this quote by Nelson Mandela, “I learned that courage was not the absence of fear, but the triumph over it. The brave man is not he who does not feel afraid, but he who conquers that fear.” You are right, sadness makes us value happiness even more. I'm happy that you think the same way as me :-) It's so nice to have someone with similar thoughts, to share feelings with :-)

From what I hear, high school in China must really be tough, with so much pressure, and from what you tell me, very boring. It seems like school in Germany is the other extreme, students are treated very nicely, sometimes too nicely. For instance, parents would blame teachers if their kids do not get good marks, or even if they get too much homework. In a way, it encourages kids to be lazy. Only afterwards, when they grow up, they realize that they have not worked hard enough, and regret it when it's too late... Also, kids get a lot of freedom, a lot of free time. For those who find things and activities they like, it's great, but it's also easy to lose orientation, just fooling around, not knowing what to do with life. That can also be scary. So there are good and bad sides everywhere, in every system, there is no perfect solution. I guess, it's not where we grow up that matters, what really matters is that we try to make the best out of it. And look at you, I would say you are doing very well, and I'm sure that it will only get better and better :-)

That sounds great, you will teach! Now it's your turn to inspire students :-D That's very exciting. Maybe you can tell me more about it when we skype? See, hear, and talk to you tomorrow :-D

Best wishes,
X

Nash must have been a special character, in positive and negative ways. I learned that he and his wife died in a car accident this month, coming home from Norway where he received the Abel Prize. Tragic, isn't it?

Yes, that's great, you can call me via Skype on Wednesday, at 20:00 local time in France (which is 19:00 London time). It's a good time for me. So I'll just wait for you, and make sure that I'm online and logged into Skype.

Dear R,

yes, absolutely, feedback is very important. If it's positive, then that's nice, but if it's negative (and honest), then we can actually learn even more. For instance, last year, my teaching was not so good. It was my first time teaching in the UK, and I was not familiar with the material of the module. So I focused on giving good lectures, explaining all the proofs in detail. For those students who paid attention, it was fine, but quite a few got bored and even started to get noisy; also, students were afraid of the proofs, especially in the exam. This year, I changed things a bit. Not the material of the module, and I also did all the proofs, but I would ask questions during my lectures to keep the attention up, and I would summarize the ideas of very long proofs. I even spent half an hour to discuss the importance, and also the beauty, of proofs. These little changes made quite a difference.
